content: @Timothy Maloney was asking me about parallel rustc, told them that it may be a good idea to document what they find about parallel because our documentation is poor/lacking
also tying this with GloRuWriClu, it may be one of the areas to cover, we may be able to get an expert to provide a lecture or something

Santiago Pastorino said:

Timothy Maloney was asking me about parallel rustc, told them that it may be a good idea to document what they find about parallel because our documentation is poor/lacking

parallel_compiler is on hold right now, though, right?

Santiago Pastorino said:

Timothy Maloney was asking me about parallel rustc, told them that it may be a good idea to document what they find about parallel because our documentation is poor/lacking

@Santiago Pastorino GloRuWriClu is on hold. Two reasons. First, we lost both of the tech cohort leads, and second, Niko is working on a different approach. There will be a project that focuses on a Code Reading Club and a second effort that uses example rust code and walks/follows it through rustc to learn how rustc works.
The goal is for the Code Reading Club is to start between mid and late September. More details will be coming soon.

There will be a project that focuses on a Code Reading Club and a second effort that uses example rust code and walks/follows it through rustc to learn how rustc works.

That sounds interesting! It would be great to learn more about parts of the compiler I'm unfamiliar with.

Doc Jones said:

Santiago Pastorino said:

Timothy Maloney was asking me about parallel rustc, told them that it may be a good idea to document what they find about parallel because our documentation is poor/lacking

Santiago Pastorino GloRuWriClu is on hold. Two reasons. First, we lost both of the tech cohort leads, and second, Niko is working on a different approach. There will be a project that focuses on a Code Reading Club and a second effort that uses example rust code and walks/follows it through rustc to learn how rustc works.

yes I'm aware, I meant to say, whatever approach we can come up with or the previous one we followed in the past, may be good means to document rustc parallel

In the overview and query sections of the High-Level Compiler Arch section there are sub-sections that discuss the parallelism in codegen, and the parallelism in the query system.

I am going to move all these and all sub-sections that discuss parallel compilation to the parallel compilation sub-section, so that everything parallel- related is in one place. I am wondering what people think about this before I go ahead and do it.
